subject: Self Care
title: Stress and the Racing Mind
description: A quick win: understand Stress and the Racing Mind.

hook.text: You're exhausted but the moment you lie down, your brain replays every worry from the entire day.

buildup.text: Stress triggers cortisol, the alertness hormone. High cortisol at night is the opposite of what sleep needs.

discovery.text: The brain's default mode network activates when you're idle. It surfaces unresolved thoughts at bedtime.

twist.text: Trying to force yourself to sleep increases anxiety about sleeping, making insomnia even worse.

climax.text: Writing worries down before bed externalizes them. The brain relaxes once thoughts are captured outside.

punchline.text: Dump your worries on paper. Let the page hold them.

quiz.question: Why does writing worries before bed help sleep?
options: Externalizing thoughts lets the brain release them
